page.title: 07TREVOLLARD FARM - TREMATON
page.content: Trevollard farm covers about 75 acres and holds some 320 sheep and 40 cattle. The farmer, brought up in London bought the farm in 1975 after spending 8 years in New Zealand. His Leeds born wife lived in South Africa before joining him. Together they took over what had been an arable/market gardening farm in the same hands for some 49 years. The farmhouse dates from the 1850s, reputedly built by a smuggler and having underground passages. At one time it served as an Old Peoples home. Electricity and mains water reached it in 1967. During World War II German Prisoners were employed here. A quarry was apparently dug in 1850, the same year in which dock dung was introduced - rubbish from the streets of Plymouth sold for eight pounds per 200 tons.
